As we move into the 2020-2021 student data environment of Infinite Campus, we have encountered a new situation. Parents/guardians of our incoming kindergartners are currently able to view a field in the Parent Portal that indicates whether their child is in AM or PM kindergarten. Please note that you will only have access to the Parent Portal if your child's registration is complete and approved. Notice of access to the Parent Portal will automatically be sent to you when the registration is finalized.

The information is NOT accurate and should NOT be considered to be a final representation of your child’s assignment for the upcoming year. Final AM versus PM assignments will be communicated to you in writing from the district and will reference your specific child. We apologize for the inconvenience and appreciate your understanding!

Good Evening,

This message is being sent on behalf of the Berks Career and Technology Center:
As of late this afternoon, several Berks County Schools have made the decision to close for a period of time. We have received telephone calls asking what this means for students from these districts who attend BCTC. Following our protocol for closures, BCTC students who attend a sending school district that is CLOSED is not to attend BCTC during the time of closure nor will BCTC provide bus transportation to and from those districts. Again, if your school district is CLOSED your son or daughter is not to attend BCTC nor will transportation be provided. We thank you for your patience and understanding. We will continue to keep you and our students informed of any changes that may occur to the BCTC schedule. Please visit the BCTC website at www.Berkscareer.com for the latest information.

Thank you!
James A. Kraft, Ed.D.
Executive Director
Berks Career and Technology Center

Earlier in February, BASD’s four chapters of the Technology Student Association participated in TSA’s Region 9 Conference in Stroudsburg, PA. Our teams, representing BASH, Freshman Academy, MSE, and MSW combined for 39 1st place, 37 2nd place and 30 3rd place finishes with a remarkable number of additional individual and team finishes! Members from all four district chapters will move on to compete in the PA-TSA State Conference in April!

This is the 4th time that BASH has won the Inspiration Award for Region 9.

Mrs. Sundstrom and Ms. Mallozzi, 3rd-grade teachers at Gilbertsville, have and I have implemented Problem of the Week (POW) with their 3rd-grade math students. With POW, students work on solving challenging word problems by using a variety of problem-solving strategies and lots of thinking outside the box. The students work on part of each problem independently, part with a partner, and have support from parent volunteers throughout each problem. The process is not linear – it requires the students to revise their work as they work towards finding a solution. POW gives students a chance to be exposed to real-life problems they may not normally be exposed to in the classroom.

Each day, students complete a different part of the process. Today, students received a new word problem and were tasked with determining what they noticed in the problem (what they know from reading the problem) and what they were curious about (what they would still like to know after reading the problem).

Looking forward to watching this unfold throughout the week! Way to go GES 3rd Grade!!!

Today, the MSE principals, instructional coaches, staff, and outside presenters worked together to provide a unique learning experience for the 8th graders aimed at giving them a deeper understanding of Colonial America.

Colonial dress was encouraged for 8th-grade staff and students, and some of the outside presenters were in full colonial attire.

The 8th-grade students did not have traditional classes but rather a schedule of colonial activities that they got to choose from. Activities included: Colonial Clothing and Toys, Digging Colonial America, Ciphers and a Scavenger Hunt, Dance, and Crocheting Poor Man's Lace.

The main event was an outside presenter, Noah Lewis, who plays “Ned Hector”, an American Revolutionary War soldier. His assembly is very interactive and the students were up on stage with him at times throughout the event.

Here is his Mr. Lewis' website http://www.nedhector.com

post_text: In a first of its kind event for BASD, the ENTIRE faculty and staff came together for Trauma-Informed Classroom training. The event was a HUGE success! To be in one room with 1000 teammates was truly moving. Jess and Ryan of Thom Stecher & Associates presented an educational and interactive training that had all of us reflecting, connecting, and building relationships that will impact the students of our district for years to come! We would be remiss if we did not give a shout out to our Office of Teaching and Learning for making this happen...it was an afternoon we won't soon forget!

We would like to begin by apologizing. The ONE BOYERTOWN Council Meeting on Monday evening was to be recorded in the same way that Board Meetings are typically recorded. Unfortunately, there was a misunderstanding as to the day of the meeting and we did not have staff available to record the meeting.

We did, however, have great community support in putting together the attached video from the meeting...someone video recorded...someone else audio recorded...and we collaborated to put this together...demonstrating ONE BOYERTOWN at its best.

The timeline below features the highlights in case you would like to fast forward.

0:00 Introduction
0:35 Greg Herb on the FBE
5:53 Welcome by PAC
6:42 Welcome by Dr. Bedden
11:40 Mission, Vision, and Goals
22:25 Main Presentation- Financial Sustainability
53:13 Dr. Bedden Key Highlights
1:01:30 Answers to Questions about Pine Forge
1:10:35 Answers to Audience Questions

If you have any questions after viewing the video, please contact us via email to communications@boyertownasd.org
